body:
r? @eddyb

(rust_highfive has picked a reviewer for you, use r? to override)

I'll have another look later when I can access docs, but this looks good to me code-wise. There may be a way to avoid the csearch.

I'm not certain if we want to add more lints though. @alexcrichton thoughts?
I personally feel that we have far too many lints as-is, but I'm also quite biased! I don't believe we have a strict policy on what lints are included and which are not.

So, this doesn't _need_ to be a lint. It could be built in to the `instrinsicck` code that checks all other kinds of transmutes. However, this one doesn't violate a size difference. Either way, docs saying "don't ever do this" but a compiler who happily allows it reminds me of C.
This would fix https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/13146

triage: beta-nominated

wonder if that works
Anything else required for this?

Looks good to me.

I'll let @alexcrichton r+ this though
from nominated to (nominated, accepted)

Maybe the documentation of `UnsafeCell` should be reworded. That transmuting `&` to `&mut` is “in general” undefined behavior does not mean that it is undefined behavior per se. [The reference](http://doc.rust-lang.org/1.0.0-beta.2/reference.html#behavior-considered-undefined) makes much stronger arguments.

I still personally feel that lints like this are too specific to be that beneficial. For example this does not provide an iron-clad guarantee that this kind of "undefined behavior" isn't actually happening. The biggest abuser of `&mut self` in the standard library, channels, is not caught by this change and probably wouldn't with any form of lint. I know that lints are not meant to provide an iron-clad guarantee, but I'm just not sure how useful this will end up being (especially being deny-by-default).

IMO if we crack down on UB now, even with semi effective solutions like this one; it will still be a net gain in the future when there isn't any UB abuse scattered all over the place.

-----Original Message-----
From: "Alex Crichton" notifications@github.com
Sent: ‎4/‎25/‎2015 12:24 AM
To: "rust-lang/rust" rust@noreply.github.com
Cc: "Manish Goregaokar" manishsmail@gmail.com
Subject: Re: [rust] Add lint to deny transmuting &T to &mut T (#24392)

I still personally feel that lints like this are too specific to be that beneficial. For example this does not provide an iron-clad guarantee that this kind of "undefined behavior" isn't actually happening. The biggest abuser of &mut self in the standard library, channels, is not caught by this change and probably wouldn't with any form of lint. I know that lints are not meant to provide an iron-clad guarantee, but I'm just not sure how useful this will end up being (especially being deny-by-default).
—
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

I happen to believe that any lint that's supposed to be so important to be deny-by-default should be a feature of the language proper rather than being left up to a lint. I dunno, maybe the perfect is the enemy of the good...
I'm open to warn by default

Since this is undefined behavior, I think it should be deny by default. If you somehow know better, you can add an `allow`.

I originally thought of adding this code to `intrinsicsck`, but several in `#rust-internals` said it seemed wrong since that's only supposed to enforce the values are the same size.

I do agree with @bstrie that it seems weird to implement a check for undefined behavior as a lint instead of some sort of other error. A lint is an admission that "sure, you may want to actually do this sometimes, just not all the time", but I'm not sure that we have a set of behavior where you would indeed want this kind of a transmute.
I don't know, I'm wary of building in "no, you should never need this" into a language; there should always be a way to do stuff like this, just that there are more hoops to jump through.

I saw this PR though a link from the meeting minutes that were just published (shouldn't that be an RFC since it would break code if it's deny by default?).

I don't know if it's too late, but -1 for me.

I **hate** having any kind of protection when I manipulate unsafe code. Unsafe is unsafe, and I don't want the compiler to interfere with me.

You don't write `unsafe { mem::transmute(value) }` by accident ; if you do write this code, it is either for a good reason or as a temporary work-around. All that this lint will do is make people write `let val: *const T = val; let val = val as *mut T: let val: &mut T = unsafe { &mut *val };` instead of `transmute`.

Also if you follow this idea, you should also add a lint to protect against using raw pointers (as it can be undefined behavior if the pointer is null), add a lint to protect against using `setjmp`/`longjmp`, add a lint against static mut (as it can produce data races), etc. I don't see why we would add a lint for a single undefined behavior, while there are so many in the wild.
It's a lint so you can easily ignore/override it so having it run on unsafe code seems okay to me.

But is there really a situation where someone would say: "oh, this lint detected a mistake I made, let me fix my code"?

As I said, you never transmute by accident, so instead it will be "why is this warning here? let me disable it".

> I hate having any kind of protection when I manipulate unsafe code. Unsafe is unsafe, and I don't want the compiler to interfere with me.

FWIW, I think "unsafe is unsafe" is a very good reason for the compiler to interfere: the code is dangerous, and the compiler should offer as much assistance (i.e. not hard rules) to avoid 'obviously bad' patterns such as this. I don't really know any correct reason to do this sort of transmute.

In any case, this lint is not linting against all uses of transmute, just a single case that's tempting ("argh this is too hard, let's just cast the immutability away") and unlikely to be correct. In a similar vein, I would be all for having lints that identified almost-always-bad patterns for other examples of risky behaviour you list.

Unsafe doesn't mean a free-for-all, it means the programmer needs to uphold Rust's invariant themselves and having a computer help seems like a good thing.

> the compiler should offer as much assistance (i.e. not hard rules) to avoid 'obviously bad' patterns such as this

The [other example that I have in mind](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/20031) for the compiler trying to offer assistance was in fact a bad idea (to not say stupid).
While this protection is far from being as bad, I still see it as an unnecessary interference.

> As I said, you never transmute by accident, so instead it will be "why is this warning here? let me disable it".

using `transmute::<&mut Foo, &Foo>(...)` seems like something which people would expect to work and might use it to circumvent safety restrictions. Which is fine, except that this sort of transmute is UB and might do something unexpected.
@alexcrichton updated
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #24967) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

@tomaka to me this seems very similar to other lints like the deny-by-default overlong bit shifts or possibly the new `#[repr(C)] +`Drop` lint, so I'm curious if you feel the same way about those? In general I agree with @huonw that unsafe code doesn't mean that you should have to take on all assumptions that come with it _silently_, and compiler assistance can certainly help.

I am personally not comfortable as to _where_ this lint is located, but I think that's orthogonal to whether it's a lint at all or not.

I'm not aware of this `#[repr(C)] + Drop`, but if it's a lint to warn about implementing `Drop` on types with a `#[repr(C)]`, I'd be opposed to it as well. I was also opposed to pointers not implementing `Send`/`Sync`.

For me, `unsafe {}` means `you are now writing C code`.

> But is there really a situation where someone would say: "oh, this lint detected a mistake I made, let me fix my code"?
> @tomaka In fact, the second commit in the PR is exactly that. The usage in `Sender` was a mistake, caught by this lint.

Especially with the lint message adjusted to suggest using an UnsafeCell, I imagine it would help catch more mistakes like this. Likewise, here's another example of where it would have caught a mistake: https://github.com/carllerche/pool/issues/2

I understand why you want a `#[repr(C)] + Drop` lint but I agree to tomaka opposing on this. That seems overly clucky. Was there a concrete case leading to this lint? Normally I would just assume that someone who  uses  `#[repr(C)] + Drop` on a struct does that for a reason.

@tomaka you are supposed to wrap raw pointers and C structures, not expose them directly to Rust code, that is irresponsible.

Unwrapped raw pointers can be manipulated by safe code, and implementing `Drop` is incompatible with `#[repr(C)]` because of the drop flags, and those are in 1.0, aren't they?

`unsafe {}` is **not** C code, unless you write your C code with `restrict` or `const` on all the pointers, but even then, it's easier to create UB in Rust.
Truth is, `unsafe {}` is an UB concentration point: you know where it is, but it better be correct.

This lint is useful because transmuting is how it was done before `UnsafeCell` (you also needed to add `#[no_freeze]` IIRC).

I would also argue for disallowing pointer <-> integer casts and `*const T as *mut U` by default, with friendly reminders about ASLR and requirements around mutations.
(Is it possible to have `#[allow(foo)]` just on one `unsafe` block?)

A bunch of transmutes could be safe, if we had a trait describing types for which every possible bit pattern is a valid value.

Then, unsafety would be focalized further on dereferences of raw pointers and creation of resources out of weakly typed bits (`*mut T -> Box<T>`).
Another instance: http://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/34u40n/abomonation_terrifying_serialization/cqynb6u
@seanmonstar yes it was not about this one, admittedly ambiguously formulated.

tomaka:

> But is there really a situation where someone would say: "oh, this lint detected a mistake I made, let me fix my code"?

Lints – and static code analysis in general – are regarded very positively in many language communities. E.g. many front-end devs won't allow code that doesn't pass jslint, and I (a seasoned Java dev with more than a decade of experience) have FindBugs check my code at all times. It's cheap and will sometimes catch oversights. Errors happen. Having an additional safety net cannot hurt. Rust is already very good in this regard.

So while I certainly agree that not all lints belong in rustc, I don't feel that we have too many. But I'm just a rust newbie, so feel free to ignore my opinion. :smile:

I'm with @seanmonstar on this one. The issue that I had (linked above) was something that a) seems to work fine, b) I had every reason to believe would work (exclusive ownership was guaranteed elsewhere), and c) should never be allowed by anyone serious about things. 

The suggestion to do the transmute was made by a seasoned (unnamed) Rust-y in IRC. Now that I've internalized some of the things on the UB link I know a bit better, but I could really use the help from lints written by smarter folks.

@alexcrichton updated the failing run-pass tests
@bors: r+ 5b0d828d9bd9776dc0d4158a7bd7ccba19f0ecba
:hourglass: Testing commit 5b0d828 with merge e609b8a...

Sigh, had improved the lint message from review comments, but forgot to adjust the expected error in the compile-fail. Then the subsequent check-stage1-rpass for the previous failure hadn't caught it either.

_Now_ cfail passes as well.
@bors: r+ 5624cfb
:hourglass: Testing commit 5624cfb with merge 8767e97...

:sunny: Test successful - [auto-linux-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-nopt-t/builds/4842), [auto-linux-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-opt/builds/4849), [auto-linux-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-nopt-t/builds/4806), [auto-linux-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-opt/builds/4830), [auto-linux-64-x-android-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-x-android-t/builds/4798), [auto-mac-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-32-opt/builds/4874), [auto-mac-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-nopt-t/builds/4870), [auto-mac-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-mac-64-opt/builds/4842), [auto-win-32-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-32-nopt-t/builds/4533), [auto-win-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-32-opt/builds/4518), [auto-win-64-nopt-t](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-64-nopt-t/builds/3330), [auto-win-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-win-64-opt/builds/3355)
Thanks a ton for merging this; to add to the support, after this lint appeared I found the bug in `eventual` https://github.com/carllerche/eventual/issues/21 and in my own `rust-bitcoin`.
